Question_1.Context: In the study, what method was used to improve chromatographic selectivity by minimizing matrix interference?
Question_1.Question: What method was used to improve chromatographic selectivity by minimizing matrix interference?
Question_1.Source: For unavoidable signal modification, a matrix-matched calibration curve was used to compensate for the matrix effect. Minimizing matrix interference by sample clean-up improves chromatographic selectivity.

Question_2.Context: What was the main purpose of using a matrix-matched calibration curve in the study?
Question_2.Question: What was the main purpose of using a matrix-matched calibration curve?
Question_2.B: To compensate for the matrix effect
Question_2.C: To introduce noise in the signal
Question_2.Source: For unavoidable signal modification, a matrix-matched calibration curve was used to compensate for the matrix effect.

Question_3.Context: What was the LOD value for the seven SUHs in the study?
Question_3.Question: What was the LOD value for the seven SUHs?
Question_3.Source: The LODs for the 7 SUHs were 0.003 mg kg−1.

Question_4.Context: What was the range of analyte concentrations for which the calibration curves for the seven SUHs showed good linearity?
Question_4.Question: What was the range of analyte concentrations for good linearity in the calibration curves?
Question_4.Source: Calibration curves for the seven SUHs showed good linearity, with coefficients of determination exceeding 0.9970 in the 0.156–10.0 mg L−1 range of analyte concentrations.

Question_5.Context: What was the main consideration for the LODs and LOQs obtained in the study?
Question_5.Question: What was the main consideration for the LODs and LOQs obtained?
Question_5.A: They were higher than recommended values
Question_5.B: They were lower than recommended values
Question_5.C: They were comparable to recommended values
Question_5.D: They were not reported in the study
Question_5.Source: The LODs and LOQs obtained in this study were lower than those recommended by the EU and the Korean Ministry of Food and Drug Safety.

Question_6.Context: What was the recovery range (%) considered acceptable for the seven SUHs in the study?
Question_6.Question: What was the recovery range (%) considered acceptable for the seven SUHs?
Question_6.Source: Validated method performance should comply with the SANTE/11312/2021 guidelines, with a recovery range of 70–120%.

Question_7.Context: What was the main conclusion regarding the recoveries observed for all the SUHs in the study?
Question_7.Question: What was the main conclusion regarding the recoveries observed for all the SUHs?
Question_7.Source: All seven analytes exhibited acceptable recoveries and good precision.

Question_8.Context: What was the main outcome of applying the developed method to real-life tomato samples in the study?
Question_8.Question: What was the main outcome of applying the developed method to real-life tomato samples?
Question_8.A: High levels of pesticide residues detected
Question_8.B: No SUH residues exceeding LOD values
Question_8.Source: The quantitative results revealed that none of the samples contained any of the seven SUHs in quantities exceeding the LOD values.

Question_9.Context: What was the main purpose of the method validation in the study?
Question_9.Question: What was the main purpose of the method validation?
Question_9.A: To determine the LODs and LOQs
Question_9.B: To evaluate the color removal efficiency
Question_9.C: To assess the recoveries and precision
Question_9.D: To establish MRLs for the SUHs
Question_9.Source: To evaluate the accuracy and precision of the developed method, the recoveries were determined with blank samples spiked at three fortification levels.

Question_10.Context: What was the main sorbent used for the d-SPE clean-up in the study?
Question_10.Question: What was the main sorbent used for the d-SPE clean-up?
Question_10.Source: Based on the color removal rate and analyte recovery, 300 mg of C18 was selected for the d-SPE clean-up.
